bestBHT.bht: Paul's words in this portion serve as a reminder of the arrogance prevalent in human nature, where individuals take pride in their perceived wisdom. This extends beyond the realm of ancient Greek philosophers to the general assumption of wisdom among the Greeks. The inherent flaw is that this self-proclaimed wisdom actually leads to foolishness, as seen in the depraved acts of idolatry and the grotesque attempts to create false deities. These vain efforts to present distorted images of divinity epitomize the tragedy of humanity's misguided pursuit of wisdom.

Henry Alford: while they professed themselves wise—professing themselves to be wise
The words relate perhaps not so much to the schools of philosophy, as to the assumption of wisdom by the Greeks in general
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: It is the invariable property of error in morals and religion, that men take credit to themselves for it and extol it as wisdom.
Albert Barnes: Professing themselves to be wise - This was the common boast of the philosophers of antiquity."
They became fools - They became really foolish in their opinions and conduct.
Sinners of all kinds are frequently spoken of as fools in the Scriptures.
John Calvin: The arrogance then which is condemned here is this — that men sought to be of themselves wise, and to draw God down to a level with their own low condition, when they ought humbly to have given him his own glory.
The higher the advancement of the nations in refinement and philosophy, the greater, as a general rule, the degradation and folly of their systems of religion.
This is the greatest unhappiness of man, not only not to feel his malady, but to extract matter of pride from what ought to be his shame. What they deemed to be their wisdom was truly their folly.
Philip Schaff: Professing themselves to be wise...This has reference, not to heathen philosophers, but to the conceit of wisdom which lay back of heathenism itself.
Their folly was manifested in their idolatry.
Instead of the practical recognition and preservation of the truth thus given comes the self-wisdom rendering them foolish, and idolatry in its train.
Archibald T. Robertson: An oxymoron or sharp saying, true and one that cuts to the bone.
Paul shows indignant contempt for these grotesque efforts to present pictures of a deity that had been lost.
John Gill: Professing themselves to be wise....they became fools."
They appeared to be so; they showed themselves to be such in those very things they prided themselves with the knowledge of.
Socrates, after he had asserted the unity of God...yet one of the last actions of his life was sacrificing a cock to Aesculapius.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 1:22, the apostle Paul condemns the arrogance of those who profess themselves wise, highlighting the foolishness of their claims. These words are not only directed at the ancient Greek philosophers, but also speak to the vanity and pride of humanity throughout history. It is characteristic of moral and religious error that people take credit for it and exalt it as wisdom, even idolizing false gods along the way. This arrogance is a grotesque attempt to present a distorted image of the divine. The more societies advance in philosophy and refinement, the more their systems of religion often degrade into foolishness. Rather than recognizing and upholding the truth, they embraced self-wisdom, rendering themselves truly foolish. It is a tragic irony that pride comes not from recognizing their own shortcomings and seeking humility, but from their very shame.

In this verse, Paul exposes the folly of those who proclaim themselves wise, a character trait seen not only among ancient Greek philosophers, but in the broader context of humanity's vanity and pride. These individuals delude themselves into thinking their false beliefs are wisdom, even going so far as to idolize false gods. As societies progress in philosophy, their religious systems too often descend into foolishness. It is a tragic irony that pride arises, not from humility and self-awareness, but from embracing shame.

In this passage, Paul addresses the arrogance of those who consider themselves wise, which extends beyond ancient Greek philosophers to the wider notion of human vanity. People often take credit for and extol their moral and religious errors as wisdom. This prideful pursuit of self-wisdom leads them into idolatry, distorting their understanding of the divine. As societies advance in intellectual pursuits, their religious systems often deteriorate into foolishness. It is tragically ironic that instead of recognizing their shame, they derive pride from their folly.

Those who boast of their wisdom, as Paul criticizes in this verse, are not only confined to ancient Greek philosophers, but can be observed throughout history. In their pursuit of self-proclaimed enlightenment, they become fools, indulging in morally and religiously erroneous ideologies. Idolatry is the consequence of their self-wisdom, distorting their perception of the divine. It is lamentable that as societies progress intellectually, their religious systems often devolve into foolishness. Thus, their supposed wisdom becomes a source of pride, instead of acknowledging their shame.
